dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRAIRIE DAY
dialogues.text: Panoramic shot of western prairie. In the far distance WE SEE a speck of activity on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS BEGIN
dialogues.text: Over credits we HEAR our title song, THE LOVE THEME FROM BLACK BART, Title on screen reads:

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS AS TONY BENNETT AND FRANKIE LAINE
dialogues.text: We HEAR the faint SOUNDS of clanking and voices. As CAMER GETS CLOSER we begin to make out shapes of men hard at wo CAMERA CONTINUES TO MOVE IN. Through the heat shimmer we are now able to distinguish t this is a railroad work gang made up of Blacks, Chinese a Irish immigrant laborers. They are hard at work laying track westward, under the watchful gaze of cruel overseer

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: the assistant foreman, walks into frame. He is obviously dissatisfied. He is flanked by two cruel overseers. He takes out a pocket watch, glances at it and puts it back.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: C'mon boys. The way you're lolly- gagging around here with them shovels you'd think it was 120 degrees. Couldn't be more than 114. Ha, ha, ha. A Chinese man falls over from the heat.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (continuing) — Dock that chink a day's pay for napping on the job.

dialogues.speaker: OVERSEER
dialogues.text: Right, Lyle.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Now c'mon boys, where's your spirit? When you were slaves you sang like birds. How about a good old nigger work song.  2.

dialogues.speaker: GANG OF BLACKS CUT TO
dialogues.text: They are sweating profusely, They look at each other. Our hero, BLACK BART, shuffles forward. He is a handsome wiry black man in his late 20's. His appearance suggests that he is somewhat ahead of his time. He takes off his hat, mops his brow in good old darkie fashion and then turns t his fellow workers and nods. They hum a chord.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (segues into up-tempo, Sinatra-style rendition of:)

dialogues.speaker: SO TELL ME WHY SHOULD IT BE TRUE
dialogues.text: THAT I GET A KICK OUT OF you," Bart's singing is beautifully backed up in Pied Piper fashion by his co-workers.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE AND OVERSEERS
dialogues.text: Looking at each other in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Hold it! Hold it! What the hell is that shit! I meant a song. Something like "Swing Low Sweet Chariot". A song!

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: and his co-workers, They pretend to be puzzled. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Don't know that one, huh? Well, how about "De Camptown Ladies". Every darkie worth his soul knows "De Camptown Ladies", Bart turns to his co-workers in mock confusion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/73 6 (Cont.) 7A.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: "De Camptown Ladies". "De Camptown Ladies". His co-workers go along with the put-on, Co-workers ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (exploding) Aw, you know! "Camptown Ladies Sing Dis Song, Doo-Dah, Doo-Dah". A few of the overseers come in and help out. Lyle and overseers singing and strutting in traditional stupid minstrel style.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: "De Camptown Ladies Sing Dis Song, Doo-Dah, Doo-Dah. De Camptown Race Track Five Miles Long, All The Doo- Dah Day. All The Doo-Dah Night, ALL The Doo-Dah Day",

dialogues.speaker: BLACK WORKERS
dialogues.text: They all stand around, their arms folded, nodding ~ appreciatively at the impromptu concert. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: LYLE AND OVERSEERS
dialogues.text: singing and strutting.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: "Bet My Money On The Bobtail Nag, Somebody Bet On De Bay. All The Doo-Dah Night, All The Doo-Dah Day, Bet My Money On The Bobtail Nag, Somebody Bet On.... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MAN ON HORSEBACK APPROACHING TE
dialogues.text: The man is TAGGART, the burly heartless, foreman. Taggart rides over and strikes Lyle on the head with a swagger stick.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: What in the wide, wide world of sports is going on here? TI hired you to get some track laid, not to jump around like a bunch of Kansas City faggots.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Taggart...got caught up.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Listen, shithead. Surveyor says there might be some quicksand up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Okay, 1'11 send down a team of horses to test the ground.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (smashes him on head with swagger stick) Horses: Are you crazy? We can't afford to lose horses. Send two niggras.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: You and you. Lyle points to Bart and CHARLIE, another black worker.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: But, sir, he specifically asked for two niggras. To tell a family secret, wy grandmother was Dutch. Are you familiar with Holland? Well, you know where Antwerp cuts off Rotterdam? Well, right there we ran this little after hours windmill... (apical exploding Get on that handear and take it down to the end of the line. Bart and Charlie walking to the handcar.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I had no idea your Grandmama was Dutch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Well, Grandfather said she was always hanging around with a lot of dykes. They crack up and slap each other off. They hop on the handcar and start pumping their way down the track. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the handcar moving along the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pumping. Suddenly they come to a dead stop. They stare at each other and slowly they begin to sink out of the frame. We HEAR a strange gurgling noise.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: 4m I wrong or is the world rising?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: I don't know but whatever it is, I hate it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Lh. MASTER SHOT BART AND CHARLIE waist deep in quicksand.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Hey Charlie, let me ask you something. Now don't be too hasty with your answer. Put some thought to it. What is it that's not exactly water and it ain't exactly earth and when it sucks you under it squeezes the last shred of breath out of your lungs till you die? Bart and Charlie look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12. TAGCART AND LYLE caro ride into the scene, a look of disgust on their faces. Taggart climbs down off his horse and throws his hat down.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Quicksand. Shit. Now we're in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: in quicksand up to their necks.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: They're in trouble. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Now let's see here, we can't go straight ahead and we can't swing vight because of this ravine. We're gonna have to turn north... He turns around toward the direction of Bart and Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (continuing) «..to Rock Ridge. (to Bart & Charlie) Would you folks hold it down just aminute. We are trying to get some work done here. We can't hear our- selves think with all that "help" going on. Now let's see... cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (softer) Help. Help. Two human beings dying. <ConTINUED)  7. 15 (Cont.) CHARLIE; Two brothers heading for the basement. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Holy cow! Hurry, Lyle, get a rope. Lyle gets rope from saddle - twirls loop over his head vigorously,

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (continuing; impressed with this fancy twirling) Hey, Lyle, can you still do that fancy thing with the rope?

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'll try. Lyle does fancy rope act - jumps through loop and other elaborate rope tricks. oot To.

dialogues.speaker: 16A, BART AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: staring at each other in disbelief. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Wanna see the Hang Dog Tail?

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: No, better hurry and get that rope in there.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They heave a sigh of relief.  19. 194. 20.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE CUT TO
dialogues.text: He skillfully tosses the rope in their direction. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BART AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They stare in amazement as the rope sails over their head way out of reach. It loops around handle of handcar.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART AND LYLE
dialogues.text: Lyle is tying end of rope to back of wagon.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Hurry up. There's $400 worth of handear sinking there. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Handear! Hey you stupid sonova- bitch, what about us? Taggart walks over to edge of quicksand where Bart is straining to reach an overhanging branch. Taggart places his boot heel on Bart's forehead. TAGGART; Now that's the kind of attitude that holds you people back. Maybe if you had a little respect for your betters you could make your way up in this world.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Up. That's what we want - up! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Lemme get back to you on that... Lyle. Taggart walks away. In a last desperate effort, Bart mana to grab on to the handcar. Charlie grabs Bart's legs and two are pulled out together with the handear. They lie th trying to catch their breath.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (to the exhausted Bart and Charlie) Okay boys, the break is over. Let's not lie around taking sun baths. Won't do you much good anyway. Taggart and Lyle are convulsed by Taggart's dry wit.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (continuing) Here, put this shovel to some good use. He drops shovel on the ground next to Bart and walks back toward Lyle. Bart grabs shovel, stands up and takes vicio practice swings with it. Charlie looks at Bart.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don't do it baby.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: I have to! Bart starts walking toward Taggart and Lyle.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: We're in a heap of trouble and we're going to need a lot of extra supplies. Write this down. Lyle pulls out paper and pencil.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now wire the main office in Topeka and tell them that I... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART

dialogues.text: Rider on horseback pulls up to Capital building steps. A little to the right of him we SEE a stagecoach in the process of being held up. Bandits with black bandanas over their faces point guns at men and women who stand with their arms raised. Rider pays no attention to scene. He rushes up steps into building.

dialogues.text: of map on wall. Map depicts the progress of the railroad construction. Finger enters FRAME and points to end of red line on map. SLOW ZOOM BACK TO REVEAL Taggart standing in front of map, pointing. His head is swathed in bandages. His hat rests way atop bandages.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (pointing) And right here, Mr. Lamarr, is where we ran into the quicksand. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 (Cont.) He touches forehead tenderly. He is still‘obviously in gr pain.

dialogues.speaker: HEDLEY LAMARR
dialogues.text: He studies map intently.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Quicksand. Quicksand...splendid.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: So now the railroad's gotta go through Rock Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (carefully digesting the news) Rock Ridge. Rock Ridge...splendid.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Yes, sir...yes, sir. Rock Ridge... Rock Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Be still, Taggart. My mind is aglow with whirling transient nodes of thought careening through a cosmic vapor of invention. There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Ditto.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, the Dr. Gillespie killings. Do your best. Lamarr pulls down the shade. There is an incredible CRASH outside as the man in the wheelchair goes through the tra door.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Now where were we...oh, yes. Rock Ridge. When that railroad comes through Rock Ridge, the property there will be worth millions and I want it. I want that land so badly I can taste it.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: takes Lamarr's words literally. He tries to imagine eatin dirt. He doesn't like it.

dialogues.text: Mv . — LAMARR:

dialogues.text: Unfortunately there is one thing that stands between me and that property, and that's the rightful owners. There must be a way of scaring them out.*

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: What about killing the first born male child in each household,

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: No, that's been done to death.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: I don't think we have anything to worty about. We can work up a number six on them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Number six? I don't think I'm familiar with that one.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: That's just where we ride into town at dawn thrashing everything that moves to within an inch of its life...except the women folk, of course.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Oh, you spare the women?

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Oh no, we rape the shit out of them at the number six dance that follows.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: It sounds grotesque but enter- taining...just might work. (Lamarr notices Taggart's bandages for the first time) Why Taggart, you've been hurt.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. This uppity niggra hit me with a shovel and f would appreciate it if you could find it in your heart to hang him. He's locked up downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Consider it done. Lamarr raises window shade. Through window WE SEE a rider and horse being led up to the gallows. Boris places one noose around the rider's neck and another noose around th horse's neck.

dialogues.text: People are walking up and down street. A little boy is rolling a hoop. A buckboard with happy family drives by. People pass and tip their hats in greeting.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN STREET CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: (v.0.) : THE TOWN SALOON WAS ALWAYS LIVELY. Men at bar, they are all drinking and chatting politely. small herd of cattle moves through the saloon. cuoriis : (v.0.) BUT NEVER NASTY OR OBSCENE.

dialogues.text: A big dirty animal of a man. He cleans shot glasses by sp ting into them and wiping them with his filthy apron..

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Band of desperados led by Taggart and Lyle swoop into town. They FIRE wildly in the air. People scatter and horses rear in fright. They ride through the center of town performing various frontier cruelties: overturning buckboards, riding by and whomping citizens over the head.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: He comes out of his office,

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: What's the meaning of this? Taggart's men shoot the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (continuing; as he is oing down. Oh, that's the meaning.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: (v.0. ARE WE TO STAY OR UP AND QUIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We discover that the "BALLAD OF ROCK RIDGE" is being sung by townsfolk. They are holding open hymnals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/73 CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: 44, REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Standing at pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: REV. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Be seated. People sit.

dialogues.speaker: REV. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I don" t have to tell you good folks what's been happening to our beloved little town. Sheriff murdered, crops burned, stores ransacked, people stampeded and cattle raped. The time has come to act and act fast. I'm leaving. Reverend starts off platform. Townsfolk ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: 444A, GABBY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: a grizzled little grub-staker in shredded, but stylish, buckskins. He chaws tobacco and spits great globs of brownish gook as verbal punctuation.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Hol' on. Consarnit, goll-darnit. I'll be a horn-swaggeled bush- whackin' side-windin' saddle horn .».Ravvid, ravvid, ravvid... : (the rest of his dialogue is completely incomprehensible)

dialogues.speaker: 44B. TOWNSFOLK
dialogues.text: There is total silence in the church as everyone carefull digests what has just been said. Gabby sits.  21. Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: 44C, OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: He rises slowly and majestically and faces the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Now how can we argue with that. LI think we are all indebted to Gabby Johnson here for clearly stating what had to be said, And I'm glad the children were here today to hear that speech, Not only was it authentic frontier gibberish.,,but it expressed a courage that is little seen in this day and age. I mean, what are we made of? Our fathers came across the prairie, fought Indians, fought drought, fought locusts, fought Dix. Remember when Richard Dix came in here and tried to take the town away? We didn't give up then and by gum we're not giving up now. Olson Johnson sits.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SAMUEL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (he rises) Olson Johnson is right. What kind of people are we anyhow? I say we stay and fight it out.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (rising) Dr. Samuel Johnson's right about Olson Johnson's being right. And I'm not giving up my ice cream parlor that I built with these two hands for nothing or nobody.

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Howard Johnson is right.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Van.

dialogues.speaker: REV. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Well, if we're gonna stay, and I think it's a big mistake, we're gonna have to have us a sheriff. Who's it gonna be?  44D (Cont.) Pause. 22. Revised 2/22/73 REV. JOHNSON: (Cont.) All right, nominations for the office of Sheriff Johnson are now in order.

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I say we nominate Olson.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I am honored. But I must decline on the grounds of I won't do it. LI nominate Van Johnson,

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I am not unaware of the prestige and the honor of the office of Sheriff. I am also not unaware of the death that frequently accompanies the job. I am thereby forced by good sense and fear to decline.

dialogues.speaker: REV. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: This town can't survive without a sheriff to keep the peace. Now, who's it gonna be? Everyone shuffles in their seats uneasily. A little boy (Henry) breaks away from his mother, jumps into aisle and makes speech.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I want to be the sheriff. I can do it. TI can do it. Please make me the sheriff. Please make me the sheriff. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS OF CITIZENS
dialogues.text: seriously considering it. Congregation ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Why don't we wire the Governor to send us a sheriff. Why should we get our own men killed? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Howard Johnson is absolutely right. We'll wire the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Let us pray for the deliverance of our new sheriff. The congregation will rise. They all rise.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) I will now read from the books of Matthew, Mark, Luke and... Shattering of glass as some lighted dynamite comes through window, ?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) DUCK. There is a huge explosion.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal smoke-filled room. GOVERNOR WILLIAM J, LE PETOMANE is at one end of table flanked by his voluptuous, crimson-haired secretary, Miss Stein, and Hedley Lamarr. Governor Le Petomane is a silver-haire silver-tongued moron. Other men at table are state officials, politicians, ward heelers, etc. Lamarr shoves a paper in front of Le Petomane.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Sign this, Governor, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46A (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Under the provisions of this bill, the Cheyenne nation would give us 200,000 square acres of their land which we have deemed unsafe for their use at this time.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Oh, wonderful. What are we giving them in return?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: & box of these. Lamarr takes out hi-1li paddle and displays it.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Seems like a fair exchange. (lowers his voice) You think you could save one of . those beauties for me? Woo-Woo.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Of course, sir. If you'll just sign here. Lamarr then takes Le Petomane's right hand and guides it through the signature. A small herd of cattle passes through his office,

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Work, work, work. What's next?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Just one more bill for you to sign, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: This is the bill that will convert the state hospital for the insane into the William J. Le Petomane Memorial Gambling Casino for the insane. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (rising to his feet) This bill will be a giant step forward in the treatment of the insane gambler.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Beautifully put. No wonder they call you the silver-tongued orator.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (sitting down) Thank you, Heddy.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: It's not Heddy, Governor... Hedley, Hedley Lamarr.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (friendly aside) What are you worried about? This is 1874... you can sue her.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Just sign here.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (as his hand is being pushed along paper) Watch the n's. Watch the n's. Cross the T, cross the T... if you don't cross the T it looks like a big L and ya get Le Pelomane, Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: MISS STEIN
dialogues.text: Just this urgent telegram from Rock Ridge that came in last Friday.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Read it... read it. (under his breath) You wild bitch.

dialogues.speaker: MISS STEIN
dialogues.text: (reading telegram) "Sheriff murdered. Church meeting bombed, reign of terror must cease, send new sheriff immediately", (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46A (Cont.2) There is 26.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (rising to his feet) Hrumph, Hrumph... murdering sheriffs, bombing churches, innocent women and children blown up. Normally I wouldn't give a damn, but this is an election year and we've got to protect our phoney, baloney jobs. general hubbub at the conference table. (rising) Gentlemen, please rest your sphincters. As. Attorney General, I assure you a suitable sheriff will be found to restore the peace in Rock Ridge. Meeting adjourned. Excuse me, Governor, I didn't mean to overstep my bounds. You say that.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Meeting is adjourned. Lamarr leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Oh, it is.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: No, Governor. You say that.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Good man but he's nervous. Tall people are very nervous. Too far from the earth. Give me one of those things, will ya sweetheart. Miss Stein hands him a hi-li paddle. Does four swipes at the ball. Misses every time, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: These are defective. Throws it back into the box and EXITS, cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamarr is pacing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: A sheriff, a sheriff. But law and order is the last thing I want. (he stops and smiles) Perhaps I can turn this to my ad- vantage. If I can find a sheriff who so offends the citizens of Rock Ridge that his very appearance would drive them out of town. But where would I find such a man? We HEAR the noises of a commotion. Lamarr goes to window and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart is being led to the front of a long line of men waiting to be hanged.

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT FRONT OF LINE
dialogues.text: Hey, what's goin' on, I'm next. Men ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (to guard) Perhaps we better wait. After all they were here before me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 (Cont.) Guard pushes Bart up steps. Bart mounts steps to scaffold Boris places noose around his neck. BORIS; Would you care for a blindfold or an after dinner mint?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: No, thank you. Do you have any- thing in the way of a reprieve? o BORIS: Thorry.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: (reading from state document) In accordance with the ordinance signed by John Mordinance, the prisoner is to be hanged by his neck to pay for sub-ordinance. If the prisoner has no last words, we'll proceed with the hanging. Hang him. Boris reaches for lever.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, Last words, last words. I£ you don't mind, I'd like a brief chat with my maker before I meet him in person.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Of course. Bart whips off his hat.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Let us bow our heads in prayer. Oh Lord, I don't know why I'm being hung but it really doesn't matter. He slowly slips noose from around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) Because sooner or later all who walk upright must take the long nap. He surreptitiously edges his way down the steps and quiet makes his way through the courtyard. No one sees him because all heads are bowed in prayer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yea verily, the leaves that are green in the spring must soonith or ‘later turnith brownith in the fallith. It is with love, not hatred, that I make my way toward the pearly gates of everlasting freedom. He is almost out of the courtyard when suddenly, INTO THE FRAME, pressed against his head is the long silver barrel of a 6-shooter. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal it ia held by Hedley Lamarr.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Beautifully put. I'd like a word with you - do you have a moment?

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN FLIPS TO
dialogues.text: OMITTED , . ‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamarr enters with arm around Bart. Bart is wearing a sheriff's badge. He impassively surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Governor. The drapes stop moving. Governor Le Petomane's head pops out from behind the drapes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Official business, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Be with you in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MISS STEIN
dialogues.text: (v.0.; behind drapes). What is it, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (v.o.; head ducks back behind drapes) Just a trifle, my dear. Throw a robe on...the floor is dirty. I'11 be back in a minute. Governor emerges from behind drapes tucking in his shirt tails.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. Sorry to be tardy. I was just looking out the wall. What can I do for you, Hedley.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Governor, as per your instructions, I'd like you to meet the new sheriff of Rock Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (to Bart) I'm pleased to mee... (to Lamarr) Lamarr, have you gone berserk? This man's a nigger. (to Bart) No offense, son.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Have a seat, sheriff, while we straighten this little matter out. Bart goes to corner of room and sits. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Lamarr, I have never questioned your judgment before but haven't you taken a giant leap away from your own good senses? You can't make a nigger (to Bart) no offense... (to Lamarr) the new sheriff of Rock Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Now don't fly off the handle, Governor. I am about to make you an historic figure, maybe get you a cabinet post.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Cabinet post? Cabinet post?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: The first man to ever appoint a black sheriff. Just think of it, Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln, Le Petomane.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: But it won't work. They'll never accept him. They'll kill that nigger (to Bart) no offense (to Lamarr) dead in one day.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: One day is all we need for your fame to be secure in the annals of Western history. And that will surely secure you the nomination for, dare I say, the Presidency? go LE PETOMANE: Dare, dare.

dialogues.speaker: . LAMARR
dialogues.text: The Presidency. Governor strides over to Bart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (humming "Hail To The Chief") Good luck nigger, no offense. And I hope that you bring glory, brief as it may be, to this hallow state.

dialogues.speaker: MISS STEIN
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Bill are you coming back?

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (deftly stepping out of his trousers Is that it Heddey, I'm terribly busy.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Of course, of course, affairs of state.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Very, very funny. You know I can still have you fired. Can I fire you?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: No, you can't, Governor.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: All right, good luck. Governor Le Petomane goes behind the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET ROCK RIDGE DAY
dialogues.text: People are busy preparing for the arrival of their new sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Hurry up, get those flags up, he'll be here soon,  33.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: running up street holding telegram.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Just got a telegram from the Governor's office, Sheriff'll be here at noon.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (holding Laurel wreath and reading from paper) Noon! I'd better rehearse my speech. ‘As’ honorary :chairman of :the wélcoming committee, it is my privilege to extend to you a laurel and hearty handshake.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SAMUEL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Gabby, can you see him yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabby Johnson is looking through telescope.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Nope. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRAIRIE DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP on the word "GUCCI" imprinted on saddle bag. PULL BACK to reveal Black Bart riding across the prairie decked out in spectacular duds, He is wearing a sensation white suit, cut in Doc Holiday fashion. He sports some violet shades, wears a dynamite Stetson, and his boots ar fashioned of white lizard. He moves like a moist dream across the prairie, his horse stepping out tastefully to big bad beat of the Count Basie band. As Bart moves out o the FRAME WE SEE, set up on the prairie, the entire BASIE ORCHESTRA, THE COUNT himself seated at the "88".  61. 62- 62A. 63. 64. 65. 65A. 65B.
Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock Ridge. OMITTED.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: He looks through telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stagecoach being held up.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: He shifts telescope to opposite horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through telescope, an indistinct shape on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: The sheriff's coming,  66. 67. 34A. Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: on platform.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Ring out the church bells. Strike ' up the band. WE HEAR church bells ring out. Band PLAYS P.D. MARCH MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figure om horse becomes more and more distinct. Finally, we see, clear as day, our black hero.  68. 69. 70. 71. 35.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (to himself) Well, I'll be a tuckered plun. (he yells to townsfolk) You won't believe it, but the sheriff is a ni-- BELL GONGS drown out rest of sentence. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: DR. SAMUEL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: The sheriff is near. Townspeople start to cheer.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSPEOPLE
dialogues.text: (AD LIB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff is near. The sheriff is near.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: No, no, the sheriff is a ni-- BELL GONGS drown out last part of nigger.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSPEOPLE CHEERING
dialogues.text: Cheering reaches pandemonium stage. Bart is now only fifty.feet away but still cannot be seen clearly because of the dust. The dust clears. Townspeople see Bart for the first time. As his horse slowly trots down the main street, the music peters out in ragged dissonance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: placing cap over mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are frozen in a tableau of stupefaction. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: who has not seen Bart enter. His eyes are glued to his paper as he reads his speech.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: The town of Rock Ridge is happy to extend a laurel and hearty welcome to its new... (he sees Bart) nigger.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He tips his hat in acknowledgement. Bart rides to center of town and gets off his horse. Nobody moves. Their eyes follow him as he starts climbing stairs of speaker's platform. He walks up slow and steady.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSFOLK
dialogues.text: 1, Gabby Johnson, his tongue, the only thing on his face not frozen in horror, “dangtes “Exom his mouth, He shakes his head and says "Ravvid, ravvid, rav..v... it 2. A woman holding her hands over her little girl's eyes. 3. Olson Johnson slowly, silently mouthing the word, "Wow

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: on speaker's platform. He reaches inside his belt.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Excuse me, while I whip this out. A piercing SCREAM rends the air.  77. 78.
curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: screaming and fainting.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He whips out rolled up proclamation from inside his gun belt. Collective gasp of relief issues from the crowd. Bart unrolls proclamation and begins reading.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: By the power vested in me...

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSFOLK
dialogues.text: pull out their guns and begin loading them.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) .-.by the Honorable William J. Le Petomane,,,

dialogues.speaker: TOWNS PEOPLE
dialogues.text: Men who continue to load and cock six shooters, rifles an shotguns. CUT BACK TO;

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He raises his eyebrows, indicating he is growing rapidly aware of the impending danger.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing; quickening pace of his speech) ...-I hereby assume the duties of the office of sheriff in and for the township of Rock Ridge. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 (Cont.) 83. 84. Reverend Johnson, who has been standing next to Bart, leaps forward and raises his arms. He is holding a Bible.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, Gentlemen, Let's not allow anger to rule the day. As your spiritual leader I implore you to pay heed to this good book and what it has to say. Especially those instructions handed down to us by Abraham, Isaac and Solomon... A LOUD SHOTGUN BLAST blows a hole through the center of the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Unfortunately, those instructions are now somewhere over Omaha. (to Bart) Son, you're on your om. I must take shelter so as to preach another day. He crouches down into a Little ball at the base of the platforn. CUT To: TOWNS PEOPLE. They are all aiming their guns at Bart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is clearly frightened. He closes his eyes tightly as if to squeeze out a thought.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (softly; to himself) Tt might work. Bart whips out his gun and presses it to his own neck.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hold it, Next man makes a move, the nigger gets it. in a different voice as a cringing, whining plantation darkie) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 84 (Cont.) 85. 86. 87. BART: (Cont.) He means it. He means it. He'll do it. I know him.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) You bet your ass I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSPEOPLE
dialogues.text: They are bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Hold on men. He's not bluffing. He'll kill ‘im sure as shooting.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Now throw your guns down. Gentle like, no tricks.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (other voice) Please, please don't shoot. Throw down your guns. He means it. He means it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SAMUEL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Listen to him, men. He's just crazy enough to do it. Men throw down guns. Bart backs down street still keeping tightly pressed against his own neck, He spots man Van Jotinson) on.roof raising rifle. ,

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (to Van) * Drop it or I swear I'll blow this nigger's head all over the street, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ho, 87 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (other voice) Oh, Lordie, Lordie, he's desperate. Do what he says,

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Drop it, Van. .He's*serious.. , cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: 884A. VAN
dialogues.text: on roof.

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Aw, shoot. Van drops rifle from roof and it clatters to ground.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He slowly continues backing down street toward jail house

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (tearfully) Isn't anybody gonna help that poor man?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SAMUEL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Hush, Harriet, that's a sure way to get him killed,

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He is only a few feet away from the jail house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Easy now, just a few feet more. Bart suddenly makes a run for it but quickly stops him- self with a shot just past his head. The town gasps.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: That was just a warning. The next time he tries it he gets it right between the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Go along with him, son. There'll be another time. Bart eases himself, backwards very slowly, until he reaches the jail house door, other hand behind him, opening door. The last thing we see is his anguished expression as he pushes himself inside and SLAMS DOOR. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart stands with his back against the door. He heaves a great sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Made it. You are so talented. He throws his arms around himself in a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (other voice) Not here.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILROAD CAMPSITE NIGHT
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS along piles of railroad construction material Set off from the rest of the campsite by a barbed wire fence, is Taggart's headquarters. Sign on fence reads:

dialogues.speaker: KNOCK ON BARBED WIRE BEFORE ENTERING
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he. 93 (Cont.) 94. Through the fence WE SEE a campfire, men seated around it cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five of Taggart's henchmen are seated around the campfire No one talks. They are busy, noisely scraping the last of their beans off tin plates. The only SOUND WE HEAR is a vulgar symphony of eating, grunting, belching and farti Taggart steps out of his tent and approaches the campfire

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Got word there's a new sheriff in town. Who wants to kill him? ALL henchmen raise their hands like eager children in sch One man pulls another man's hand down. A squabble begins.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Taggart, Mr. Taggart, sir... I believe I have a ee-nuque idea.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Ee-nuque? Don't you mean unique?

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: That's probably what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: What's what?

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Your ee-nuque idea.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Oh. Why don't we give him to Mongo. Mongo'd sure see to his ass,

dialogues.speaker: HENCHMEN
dialogues.text: (v.o.; AD LIB) Mongo. Great idea. Have a heart Taggart. Hey, Mongo will eat him for breakfast. They all laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: What do you say, Mongo?

dialogues.speaker: REVEALING MONGO
dialogues.text: He's a huge mountain of a man. Straddled between his legs is a mammoth black cauldron of bubbling beans. He uses a fireplace shovel to get the beans into his gaping yaw of a mouth. taggart walks over io him.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Well, Mongo, how would you Like to mutilate the new sheriff? Mongo smiles and issues forth a nearly human noise.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Good boy. Mongo reaches into his boot and pulls out a huge cigar, bites end off and spits it across campfire. Mongo then sticks his entire face into the raging campfire to light his cigar, As he comes back out of the campfire we see the upper half of him quietly, smoldering.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: How you want sheriff killed? A11 at once, or little pieces?

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Use your own warped judgment.

dialogues.speaker: ROCK RIDGE
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP of fine tipped artist's paint brush being dipped into small can of white paint. The brush comes out. We follow it over to a jockey ashtray whose black face is no being painted white. CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Bart putti the finishing touches on the face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: There. That's better, Bart puts paint down on desk and picks up a sheaf of "Wanted" posters. He walks over to the bulletin board and begins tacking them up. The first three are of mean looking white outlaws. The fourth handbill is of a black man. Bart studies it, crumples it up and throws it in the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (TO CAMERA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got enough trouble without a bunch of honkies chasing his ass all over Mexico. We HEAR a tremendous CRASH coming from one of the jail ce

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: The drunk in #2 must be up. He walks over to the row of cells. Stops at #2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE a man dangling upside down, his heels caught in th rail of the upper bunk,

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Now, that's what you call hung over. (to prisoner) Are we awake?

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: We're not sure, Are we black?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Yes. We are.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Then we're awake... And we're puzzled. I better straighten myself out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 (Cont.) Jim struggles to right himself.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Need any help?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: All I can get. Bart unlocks cell door and helps Jim to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd better have something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No, thanks, Food makes me sick. Jim reaches over and takes a bottle from the upper bunk, uncorks it and drinks it clean.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Hey, if a man drinks like that and he don't eat, he's gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: When? Bart studies him carefully. CAMERA MOVES INTO Jim's face. Jim is a 40'ish, over-the-hill, leather-faced, gunfighter with the saddest eyes God ever *made.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (holding fingers to his head) Jim. But most people call me Jim.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay, Jim. Since you're my guest and I'm your host what do you like to do? What are your pleasures?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I dunno, screw...play chess. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ke. 98 (Cont.1)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Let's play chess. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tumultous town meeting is in progress. The place is bedlam. Reverend Johnson, at the pulpit, raps his gavel sharply.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Order! Order!

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Nietzche says "Qut of chaos comes order."

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Oh, blow it out your ass, Howard,

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Now everyone be quiet whilst we listen to Harriet Van Johnson, our esteemed schoolmarm; as she reads a telegram that she herself has composed to the Governor, expressing our feelings about the new sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Shyly rising to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: To the Honorable William J. Le Petomane, Governor.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: (v.o0.) Louder. We can't hear you. Speak up.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Forgive me. I'm not used to public a oeeeen she s eaks a little Touder) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 (Cont.) ur. HARRIET VAN JOHNSON: (Cont. ) We, the white God-fearing citizens of Rock Ridge wish to express our extreme displeasure with your choice of sheriff. Please remove him immediately. The fact that you have sent him here just goes to prove that you are the leading asshole in the state. People start cheering and applauding. They scatter as a small herd of cattle moves through the church.

dialogues.speaker: INT, JAIL HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bart and Jim are playing chess,

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: You mean they just rode in here, busted up the town, killed the sheriff£...for no reason?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No reason I know of. Nothing here worth takirg.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Got to be a reason. (makes chess move) I'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (of£f£-handedly) I wouldn't worry about that. You'll probably be dead before you get the answer. But I would worry about that move you just made.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Oh dear, you're right. I've just put my queen in jeopardy.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Go on, take it back.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: No, I did it and I'll have to take the consequences. I'm not a baby. (he grabs his nose and begins sucking his thumb) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Th 101 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: All right, you lose your queen. (he takes queen)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (making move with flourish) Checkmate.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (amazed)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (spelling it out) CHECKMATE,. Checkmate!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You devious son-of-a-bitch.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Forgive me. I know this is petty but I've got to do it. (he leaps to his feet and does a little dance of victory) I won. You lost. I'm great. You stink. Another game, chump? Jim shakes his head, pulls out 1/2 bottle of whiskey and finishes it. BART: . Hey, man, why do you do that to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Do you really want to know?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm seriously considering writing you up for the Reader's Digest as the most unforgettable drunk I have ever known.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Well, once upon a time they used to call me the Waco Kid, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: uo.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (jumping to his feet) Yeah, and they used to call me The Ritz Brothers. The Waco Kid. Man, he had the fastest hands in the West.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (indignantly) In the world.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: If you're the Kid, show me something.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Well, maybe years ago I could've shown you something...but today... (lifts his hands; they tremble)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: I knew you were no Waco Kid. You were just pullin' my lariat.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: All right. All right. See that king? Now put your hands on both sides of it. (Bart does so) When I go for the king, you try to grab it first.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Man, that's no contest. You're a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Never mind. When I say "go" you just try to grab it. Ready?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Go!

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He clasps his hands over the king and smiles victoriously He opens his palms and looks. inside. His expression changes to surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (he takes king from under his hat} Looking for this?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Well, raise my rent. You are the Kid,

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Was. Yeah was. I was the Kid. Every prairie rat who could draw a gun from Yuma to Laredo had to ride into town to try out the Kid, I must have killed more men than Napoleon at Moscow. Yeah, it got pretty gritty. I'd hear the word "draw" in my sleep, And then one day, walking down the street, I heard a voice behind me say "Reach for it, Mister," I spun around and there I am face-to-face with a six year old kid.. Well, I threw my guns down and walked away. Little bastard shot me in the ass, I limped over to the saloon, crawled inside a whiskey bottle and been there ever since. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 (Cont.) 106. 107. Bart picks up bottle.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Have a drink. Jim takes bottle, laughs, takes a slug.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: But that's ancient history. What's your story? What's a dazzling ur- banite like you doing put here?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Well, back in '56 my folks and I were part of this long wagon train moving west. Bart imitates a harp in traditional movie flashback manner, BART; Doong, Doong, Doong, Doong.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRAIRIE DAY
dialogues.text: WE SEE line of Conestoga wagons heading West.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Well, not exactly part of it. Several hundred yards to the rear of the main body of covered wagons, eating dust all the way, WE SEE a little wagon that is obviously less well to do than the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving the wagon is a black man. Seated next to him is his wife and his ten year old son (young Bart).

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (v.o.) You might say we were bringing up the rear, when suddenly, from out of the West, came the entire Sioux nation. And let me tell you, they were open for business. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 (Cont.) 108. 109. 110. 111. WE SEE (STOCK FOOTAGE) outlined against the horizon, a long line of Indians. They swoop down on the wagon train whooping and yelling God knows what. The wagons begin to form a classic western circle.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (v.0.) Naturally, they didn't let us travel in their circle. So, we made our own.

dialogues.speaker: A SOLITARY WAGON
dialogues.text: turning in little circles.

dialogues.speaker: INDIANS
dialogues.text: attacking. In a short time they reduce the wagon train to smoldering ashes. (END STOCK FOOTAGE.)

dialogues.speaker: LITILE WAGON
dialogues.text: It is encircled by Indians. Bart and his parents stare at them in terror.

dialogues.speaker: INDIANS
dialogues.text: They stare back in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (v.0.) You might say they were a little confused by the color of our skin. Then, in rode the big chief.  112. 113. 53. . cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: in full-feathered regalia. He stares for a long time at Bart and his family.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: (to brave in half Indian, half Yiddish) Ahm...ma.,.ma...yah...va... shvartzes? The Chief is faced with a dilemma. He thinks hard and finally comes to a decision.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Manoma...Moma...Coma... (he raises his arms to the sky) La Zehn Azoi....Luzem gayen. Abi gezunt. Chief wheels his horse and rides off, Braves follow.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: And the rest is history. (he looks up) Impressed? We HEAR the SOUND of snoring. Jim is fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Yeah, I like to keep my audience riveted, Bart goes over to Jim, throws him over his back, goes ove to the cell and dumps him on his cot and throws blanket over him. Bart then goes to a make-shift cot near desk, he lies down, pulls up blanket and reaches over to put out kerosene lamp,

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (v.0.) Good night, Sheriff. Bart smiles and shakes his head and turns out kerosene lamp.
Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: INT, GOVERNOR'S OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: The office is apparently empty. From behind the drapes we HEAR the muffled voice of Governor William J. Le Petomane singing a few bars of the immortal "Avalon". The door opens, one of the Governor's flunkies ENTERS holding a telegram. He looks around for the Governor; does not see him and is about to EXIT when he HEARS the singing. He tentatively searches the room for the source of the sound. He finally moves in the right direction toward the drapes. He pulls the drape aside revealing the Governor and Miss Stein in an affectionate embrace on a small chaise lounge. The Governor is playing a little ukulele as he sere- nades his secretary.

dialogues.speaker: FLUNKY
dialogues.text: Err...Governor.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: What?...who are you?

dialogues.speaker: FLUNKY
dialogues.text: Your brother-in-law. I work for you. Urgent telegram, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: FLUNKY
dialogues.text: Harry.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah...that's right...Harry. You say a word about this to my beloved wife, your beloved sister, and I'll have you fired and burned...give me that. He rips the telegram from the man's hand and begins to read it.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Mumble, mumble,mumble.,.ASSHOLE! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS STEIN
dialogues.text: Anything you say, Bill. She starts to turn over.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: NO! Not that...not now! This is inrageous. I must speak to Heddy. (as he EXITS) Serious business...serious business --.serious business.

dialogues.speaker: HUGE PORTRAIT
dialogues.text: on the wall over Le Petomane’s desk depicting a bride and groom. CAMERA ZOOMS INTO painting. Groom's face moves from side to side, The groom's face is that of Lamarr's,

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (working himself into a euphoric frenzy) The black sheriff scheme is working to perfection, The citizens are enraged. They should be pulling up stakes any moment. The time is right to move into Rock Ridge and snap up the land. (laughs) Today Rock Ridge, tomorrow...Laredo. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Bart are seated across the desk from each other. Jim is rolling a cigarette. Bart picks up two pieces of cigarette paper, wets the end of one and carefully glues it to the other. Jim picks up little sack of Bulldurham tobacco, proffers it to Bart.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Need the makin's? BART; No thanks, got my own. Bart takes out his own little sack, reaches into it with two fingers and spreads some of his private stock across the cigarette papers.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Ya know what they're callin' me don't you?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: ' (sealing his cigarette) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Deputy Nigger. Jim laughs, strikes a match, lights Bart's cigarette and then lights his own. Bart takes a deep drag.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (in a strained, high, breathy voice) Once I establish myself in this here place, that might turn out to be an important position.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (sniffing the air) Ah, Arizona Gold. Listen, do me a favor. Don't go out there. You can't win these people over, no matter what you do, They are just not going to accept you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: That was yesterday. This is a brand new beautiful day. You don't understand human nature. Once you establish yourself, they've got to accept you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117 (Cont.) Bart rises, snubs out his cigarette and tucks the stub in his shirt pocket and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ELDERLY WOMAN wearing a bonnet approaches Bart.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (tipping his hat) Mornin', Ma'am. And isn't it a lovely morning.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Suck wind, Nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his eyes and shakes his head. He Looks back to jail to see if Jim noticed the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: at cell window from Bart's P.O.V. He raises his forefinge and mouths "that's one."

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: continuing his walk up Main Street. He comes upon a group of fighting children. Three boys are beating up on one. Bart moves in to break tp the fight.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Three against one, come on, that’s no way to fight. The kids scatter, leaving their victim sprawled in dust. Bart bends over and notices a toy tin star pinned on the boy*s shirt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Step up ladies, gentlemen and Mongos. Dive for buried treasure. This is the exact spot where the Spanish Armada was sunk by the British Navy leaving millions in Spanish Doubloons on the bottom of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Spanish Balloons? Mongo take chance. SCREEN FLIPS;

dialogues.speaker: BART AND MONGO
dialogues.text: WE SEE Bart place helmet over Mongo's head. Mongo is alre wearing diver's suit.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Where Mongo get air?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: From this wonderful antique pump. Bart spins the wheel a couple of times. Dust flies off.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Ohhh. Good. Bart finishes fastening helmet and Mongo climbs down ladd inte well,

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Good hunting.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Begins pumping, Mongo under water in well looking around.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He stops pumping. He looks at his pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: I'm on my break. He folds his arms.  141. 142. 143. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins grabbing at his throat. He tugs on hose. A sign comes down next to him which reads: FOR MORE AIR DEPOSIT“25 CENTS Mongo pitifully searches hermetically sealed diver's suit small change. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE a huge cannon from which hangs a sign reading:

dialogues.speaker: "CANNON PHOTOS
dialogues.text: FROM THE CANNON." To the right of the cannon WE SEE an old-fashioned box camera mounted on a tripod stand. Next the camera holding a flash gun WE SEB Bart, dressed in a beret and blue smock.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Hurry, hurry, hurry. The last time this remarkable photo surprise will be offered in this territory before the new cannon laws go into effect. From o.s., WE HEAR SOUND EFFECTS, SQUISH, SQUISH, SQUISH. Mongo ENTERS THE FRAME, still dressed in his diving suit. He stops in front of the cannon and opens the front of his helmet -- a lot of water comes out.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Twenty five cents, Only one tenth of a dollar. Mongo searches fruitlessly for money.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't worry about the tariff, Pal, catch you later.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: He climbs up ladder and begins lowering himself into the barrel of the cannon.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Now remember...when the cannon roars...smile. Mongo nods his head and disappears into barrel.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (TO CAMERA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say Mongo's as smart as a '38 Buick. Bart whistles to someone OUT OF FRAME. We HEAR a loud rumbling noise and into THE FRAME we see wheeled another large capnon. The second cannon is placed in front of the first one and its barrel is lowered until the barrels of both cannons are mouth to mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Ready? From inside first cannon we HEAR Mongo's muffled reply.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Ready. Bart is handed both lanyards, he pulls them simultaneousl There is an incredible ROAR as both cannons go off. The SCREEN IS BLACKENED by smtke. cuT TO: Int. TAGGART'S TENT RAILROAD CAMPSITE CLOSEUP of Lamarr's face. He is deep in thought. CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Hmn. So he managed to outwit Mongo. It seems we have made a strategic blunder.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (v.0.) How so, Mr, Lamarr, sir? CAMERA PULLS BACK during Lamarr's next speech. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145 (Cont.) 67. LAMARR: . We have made one of the most primi- tive tactical errors in military procedure. We have underestimated our opponent, CAMERA comes to a full stop, revealing Lamarr seated in a sudsy bathtub. Seated on a stool next to him is Taggart.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Thought for sure Mongo would mash him into little sheriff meatballs. Can't understand it.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Be still! My mind is a raging torrent flooded with rivulets of thought cascading in a waterfall of creative alternatives,

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Gol durnit, Mr. Lamarr, I ain't heard such pretty talk since I seen Charles Boyer as Pepe Le Moko.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Yes sir. (in lower voice, to himself) But he sure talked lovely. For a moment, all is still as Lamarr thinks. Suddenly, Lamarr crashes his fist down into the water, drenching the nearby Taggart.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Of course! That's it!

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (brushing his soggy clothing) That's it all right. And it will work!

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: You bet it will! (raising his hand like a schoolboy) Are you taking questions now, sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Elementary, cactus-head. The Beast has failed. And when the Beast fails, it is time to call in Beauty.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Beauty?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Don't be impatient, Taggart. All in good time. All in good time. She's never failed me before. Of course: (he Laughs) She'll bring him to his knees... Where's my froggy?

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (panicked) I don't know, sir? Ah. I didn't see him when I came in.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Well look, damn your eyes, look! Lamarr searches in the tub frantically. Taggart looks all around the tent.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Oh, here it is, sir, It was under your hat.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Hurry, hurry. Give it to me. Give it to me! Taggart hands Lamarr a large green rubber frog. Lamarr takes it, kisses it and places it in tub. (to himself) That was a close one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAE IW: Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poster hangs outside the saloon. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: INVADED THE HEARTS OF EUROPE
dialogues.text: We SEE a picture of her, wearing a homburg, blue in stripe suit and smoking cigarette in long older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, cheap, makeshift affair. She sits in front of make-up mirror wearing homburg, blue pin stripe suit. She is putting on finishing touches of her make-up. There is a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Willkommen, Bien Venue, Welcome. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BOOR
dialogues.text: Hedley Lamarr enters, carrying flowers.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: For you, my dear,

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Oh, how ordinary. (calls OFF CAMERA) Leopold, put zees in vater. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/73 148 (Cont.) We HEAR the dressing room door open. A man who looks strikingly like Eric von Stroheim in "Grand Illusion" ENTERS. He is bald-headed and sports a strange neck brace. He is dressed in a WWI Gérman officer's tunic. He approaches table, lowers wooden arm, places flowers in it, snaps wooden arm back into place, thereby destroying flowers; makes sharp right face and exits. Lamarr stares after him curiously.  70. 148 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Lili, I cannot find the words that truly express my joy at the rekind- ling of our association.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Bullshit. What's ze job?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Why must it always be business with us? He moves closer to her, breathing heavily on her neck. Lili continues making up. (continuing) Why do you constantly put me off? Do you find me so...unattractive?

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Only zexually. Lamarr is stung.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now, come on, Lamarr. What's ze job?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: I want you to seduce and abandon the sheriff of Rock Ridge...think you can do it?

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Is Bismark a herring? There is a loud rapping at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: (v.0.) Five minutes.... At the same time his hand smashes through the door and WE SEE wooden arm sticking into the room.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: (v.0.; continuing) Sorry. The wooden arm is withdrawn.  149. 150. 71.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JAIL HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mongo is vertically chained with about 100 yards of heavy steel cable chain to the cell door. He is sleeping like a baby. CAMERA WIDENS to TWO SHOT. Jim is staring at Mongo in amazement. He saunters over to Bart.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Incredible. I still can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He was nothing. The bitch was in- venting the Candygram. They'll never give me credit for it. There is a RAPPING at the window. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: Framed in the window we see the same elderly woman that had insulted Bart that very morning, holding a steaming pie in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: (whispering) Sorry about the 'suck wind' this morning. I hope this apple pie will in some small way say thank you for your courage and ingenuity in defeat- ing that horrible Mongo. BART; Thank you ma'am. Much obliged. Good night. Bart closes window. As soon as the window is closed, ther is a RAPPING at the window. Bart opens it.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Of course, you'll have the good taste not to mention that I spoke to you?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Well, you've got one on your side. There is another RAPPING at the window. Bart opens it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 150 (Cont.) It is Howard Johnson. He is holding a laurel wreath.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Sheriff, I want you to have this wreath. Meant to give it to you on the day you came to town. Bart accepts the wreath.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Thank you. Much obliged. Good night. Closes window. There is another RAPPING. Bart opens window. Howard is still there.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (whispering) Of course, if anybody asks you where you got it, just tell them you stole it out of my store.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Got'cha. Bart closes window. There is another RAPPING. It's the town Barber in his smock, Barber shows Bart scissors and comb.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: I want to apologize for not being able to take you today. You come around anytime tomorrow. Give you a haircut and shave on the house. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Much obliged. Good night. Bart closes window. There is more RAPPING. Bart opens window, Barber is still there.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: The best time would be about 4 o'clock in the morning. I know I'll be free then.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Solid. Bart closes window.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Jim) I'm rapidly becoming a big underground success in this town. (CONTINUED)  150 (Cont. 1) 151. 73. Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Gee, in another 25 years you may even be able to shake their hands in broad daylight. C'mon, I don't want to be late. That Lili Von Shtupp is opening tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowpokes at bar knocking down drinks. The place is chock full of first-nighters fresh in off the trail. There is a general air of happiness and despair per- meating the atmosphere. Suddenly we HEAR drum roll. The place quiets dow as the spotlight hits the stage. COWBOY MASTER OF CEREMONIES steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: M.C.
dialogues.text: And now, ladies and cowboys, the gal you've all been waiting for...the Bay-varian Bombshell herself...let's hear it for Lili Von Shtupp. Saloon patrons give out a big CHEER. Lili enters through curtains. She is dressed in homburg, blue pin stripe suit.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Sank you, ladies and cowboys. And now, I vould like to favor you viz my vorld famous wendition of "I'm Tired"...ze song zat closed Poland. But wight before I do, I'd like to slip into somezing more comfortable... wiz your kind permission.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: You're too kind. She walks into wings and returns immediately, clad in an incredibly sexy outfit, The place goes wild. Lili signals for quiet. A hush falls over saloon. Softly, she begins to sing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: I'M TIRED
dialogues.text: Suddenly drum starts new “up tempo". Lili reaches down and snaps off her whip, cracks it and goes into release of song as she marches down into audience.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: WITH A STWANGER
dialogues.text: Lili approaches Gabby Johnson, who stares at her and giggles and is simultaneously mumbling, "Ravvid, ravvid, ravvid...

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: THAT'S THE DANGER
dialogues.text: A big ugly cowhand reaches for her breast. Without missing a beat, she knees him in the groin. He quietly faints.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: AND IT'S BWISKET
dialogues.text: Lili approaches a table at which Bart and Jim are seated and slips Bart an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: TIRED OF PLAYING THE GAME
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1521 (Cont.1) * 152. 153. She makes her way back to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: I'M SO TIRED
dialogues.text: The audience goes wild. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: BART'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Jim is applauding as Bart opens envelope and takes out note.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What have you got there?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: The lady slipped me a note.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (reading) I must see you alone in my dwessing woom wight after the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK at the door. Leopold opens it.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: I believe I have an appointment with Miss von Dyke.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (v.0.) Leopold, take the gentleman's hat. Bart hands his hat to Leopold, who takes it and transfers it to his wooden arm, crushes it and EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (looking after his hat and mumbling) I loved that hat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 153 (Cont.) Lili ENTERS. Bart hands her one red rose.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: For you.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Ooh, a wed wose...how womantic. Have a seat, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Wanks. Bart sits.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Von't you excuse me for a moment vhile I change into somezing more comfortable. Bart does take INTO CAMERA. Lili is still wearing her almost naked outfit.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing; from behind screen) Why don't you.... loosen your bullets, She comes out wearing exactly the same outfit, only different color.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing) Ah, I feel wefreshed. Isn't it bwight in here? She puts kerosene lamp out. It is pitch dark.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (continuing) There, isn't that better? There is a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Well, we've definitely eliminated the glare. There is a quiet RAPPING. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Pardon me, I'll be back in a moment. Wemember where we were. She goes to door and opens it a crack. We SEE Lamarr in the partially opened doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (whispering) How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: He's like wet sauerkraut in my hands. By morning he will be my slave. Splendid! TAMARR: She closes door.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Ah, where were we? Ah yes. Here, let me sit next to you. Tell me schatzi, it is twue vat zey say about the vay you people are gifted? (long pause) Oh, oh, it's twue, it's twue, it's twue, it's twue...

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Excuse me, you're sucking my arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bart is seated at breakfast table. She is pouring him coffee.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Vould you like another schnitzen- gruver?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: No thanks, baby, 15's my limit on schnitzengruber. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Then how about a little... (whispers something into his ear we can't hear)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, please...I'm not from Havana. (he gets up) Besides I'm late. I've got some heavy chores to do.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Vill I see you later?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Depends on how much vitamin E I can get my hands on. As he leaves she dives at his feet and clings to his boot Bart starts toward the door dragging Lili across the room

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: No, no. Please you mustn't leave. I need you. I never met anyone like you. I can't live vithout you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Please, you're making a German spectacle of yourself. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim is at the desk. Bart enters and closes the door, lean against it and sighs. He wears his crushed hat.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Well, I see you got a hat job. What else transpired during the long night?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, but I think I invented pornography. Bart walks toward desk.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's been happening in the clean word? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 155 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Bad news. Got a writ here for Mongo's release signed by Hedley Lamarr himself.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (taking the writ and studying it) Hedley Lamarr. Why would a dude like Hedley Lamarr care about Mongo? Well, it's legal. Bart takes a bucket of water and walks to where Mongo is trussed in chains and splashes it in Mongo's face.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Orange juice, toast and coffee...and a paper. Mongo yawns and stretches, easily breaking out of the cha

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay Mongo. You're free. You can go... please.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: No. Mongo stay. Mongo sits on bunk.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Hey man, get outta here. You're free.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Mongo stay with Sheriff Bart. Bart first man ever whip Mongo. Mongo impressed. Have great affection tor sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better watch yourself, Bart. I do believe Mongo's takin’ a fancy to you.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Bwaah. Mongo straight.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (leoking at writ) Hey, Mongo, maybe you know: What's a big shot like Hedley Lamarr doing in a nothing town like Rock Ridge?

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Don't know for sure, but got to do with where choo-choo go. (CONTINUED )
