dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What does Hedley Lamarr care about where the choo-choo go?

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: No know. Mongo only pawn in game of life.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Choo-choo. This might be a good time to mosey out to where they're building the railroad and maybe do a little snooping.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Maybe a little snooping and maybe a lot of dying. You are one crazy nigger. I don't understand you. You're acting like a...a...sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: That's what it say on the star. C'mon. Bart and Jim start out the door.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: What about Mongo lunch?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: The stage from Yuma will be in at 2:00...eat the horses.

dialogues.speaker: RAILROAD CAMPSITE HIGH NOON
dialogues.text: The sun blazes on the backs of perspiring, sweating and profusely damp railroad workers. An OVERSEER walks throug them barking out incomprehensible orders and occasionally laying his whip across a random back. Charlie is at the water bucket. He dips ladle into bucket and starts it toward his mouth. Suddenly he stops and stares out at the prairie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can't be. Must be a mirage,

dialogues.speaker: BART AND JIM
dialogues.text: Approaching campsite. Their horses kicking up clouds of dust.  158. 159. 160. 81.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He splashes water in his face and stares again.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be... His face breaks into a grin. He drops the ladle out to meet Bart. curt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie running out to meet Bart and Jim. curt

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He reins up, jumps off his horse and runs toward

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You shifty nigger. They said you was hung.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: And they was right. Bart and Charlie embrace each other gleefully.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey ba'bro. Where'd you get that star? You win it in the claw machine?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Back off scamp. You're addressing the duly appointed sheriff of Rock Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sheriff of Rock Ridge...well don't that hump the pump. That's where the railroad is going. Rock Ridge. Bart and Jim look at each other knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: and runs

dialogues.speaker: TO
dialogues.text: Charlie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/73 160 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: That's Jim. He's my friend..,he's cool, Charlie walks over to Jim and slaps him off. Suddenly a mob of railroad workers whooping and yelling for joy descend on our group. Workers ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don't crush the brother. Check your enthusiasm. Don't be messin' up the mans vines with the soil from your toil. More and more workers crowd into the scene, They slap Bart on the back and rejoice in a brother "having made it. Suddenly a man breaks through the crowd. He is dressed in a tuxedo and cowboy hat. It is TONY MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don't you see what this means? Look ...a tin star on a black man's chest. This is a tremendous step forward. Not just for him but for all of us. Black, white, yellow and Armenian working side by side, spanning America with rails of steel to bring all of us together in a symphony of brotherhood. A large orchestra begins to play. Tony whips off his hat and sings.

dialogues.speaker: THE BENSON-FONGS, THE HUEY LONGS.
dialogues.text: Suddenly Taggart and his henchmen swoop INTO FRAME on horseback, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Just what in the wide wide world of sports is going on around here? Get back to work, Martin. Taggart spots Bart.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Holy mother of pearl. That's the niggra that hit me with the shovel. What the hell do you think you're doing with that tin star, "boy''?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Watch that "boy" shit, red neck. You're talking to the sheriff of Rock Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Well, don't that beat all. Here we take the good time and trouble to slaughter every Indian in the West and for what? So's they can appoint a sheriff that's darker than the Indians, to wit, a niggra. Well, I'm depressed. Taggart slumps down in his saddle.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (timidly) Excuse me, Mr. Taggart, sir. Hate to see you Like this. What if me and the boys shot the nigger dead. Would that pep you up?

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: It would help some.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Okay boys. On the count of three. cuT TO: his arms folded across his chest.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do that if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Don't pay no mind to that alky. He can't even hold a gun, let alone shoot it. On the count of three. One..two... three. There is fusillade of gun fire.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART'S MEN
dialogues.text: The guns scattered on the ground. They are all in the same pose; grasping their hands in pain.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: His arms are still folded across his chest. Little curls of smoke slowly rise from guns in his holsters.

dialogues.speaker: RAILROAD WORKERS
dialogues.text: (as one) Whooee!!

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He pulls out gun and holds it on Taggart and his men. BART: . Don't just stand around stunned, grasping your hands in pain. Let's have a little applause for the Waco Kid.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART'S MEN
dialogues.text: They applaud, painfully.  168- 169. 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In terror. Hand comes INTO FRAME and slaps her viciously across the cheek. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal Lamarr as slapper and Taggart as a delighted spectator. Standing against the wall, bound and gagged, is Leopold. On the wall next to him, also tied securely, is his arm.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: All right, I'm through being Mr. Goodbar. It's time to act and act fast. All my plans have backfired. Instead of people leaving, they're staying in droves.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Vhy don't you admit it; he's too much man for you. I know. You'll need an army to beat him. You're finished. Fertig! Fahrlumped! Ferucht! Lili and Leopold break into a German anthem together.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: "Ve Fahren Un Gemacht Und Schleswigs Zun GeBracht"...

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (interrupts them) Shut up. (his face lights up) Wait a minute. An army. Of course. An army of the worst dregs ever to soil the face of the West. Taggart.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: I've decided to launch an attack that will reduce Rock Ridge to ashes.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, sir?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: I want you to round up every vicious criminal and gun slinger in the West. I want: rustlers cut-throats murderers (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 168- (Cont.) 169 170. LAMARR: (Cont.) bounty hunters desperados pugs mugs thugs half-wits nitwits dimwits con men Indian Agents Mexican bandits vipers snipers muggers buggerers bank robbers train robbers horse thieves horn swaggelers bush whackers ass kickers shit kickers and Methodists.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND JIM
dialogues.text: They ride into the outskirts of Rock Ridge and they are amazed to see wagons and buckboards being loaded. It looks like everybody in town is making ready to leave. Howard Johnson sits on the lead wagon.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Sheriff. It's been nice knowin' ya'.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: What's happening here? Where is everybody going?

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: We don't know and we don't care. Read this. Bart gets off his horse and Olson hands him a poster. It reads: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Can't you see that this is the last act of a desperate man?

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: We don't care if it's the first act of Henry the Fifth. We're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Give me 24 hours to come up with a brilliant plan that will save Rock Ridge... Just 24 hours. That's all I ask... You'd do it for Randolph Scott.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSFOLK
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Randolph Scott. Randolph Scott. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: , HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Okay Sheriff, 24 hours.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILROAD CAMPSITE DAY
dialogues.text: There is a long line of villains, cut-throats and assorte scum. Most are in Western attire but some are dressed in traditional evil garb: pirates, Nazis, Mexican bandits, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 173 (Cont.) Bedouins. At the end of the line we see a small herd of cattle. Lamarr and Taggart are seated behind a table. Lyle stands at front of line keeping order. The scene looks very much like Voter's esis Lamarr ad- dresses a hulking, scar-faced beast of a man. Qualifications?

dialogues.speaker: CUT-THROAT
dialogues.text: Rape, murder, arson and rape.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: You said rape twice.

dialogues.speaker: CUT-THROAT
dialogues.text: I like rape.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Splendid. Sign here. Here's your badge.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Next.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Qualifications?

dialogues.speaker: CUT-THROAT
dialogues.text: Mayhem, arson, armed robbery...

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Just a moment. What are you chewing?

dialogues.speaker: CUT-THROAT
dialogues.text: (frantically tucking his gum under his tongue) Nuffin. Nuffim, eh? Lyle. Lyle pries open the Cut-Throat's mouth and triumphantly removes a wad of gum. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Gum. Lamarr rises to his feet trembling with rage.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Chewing gum on line. I hope you brought enough for everybody?

dialogues.speaker: CUT-THROAT
dialogues.text: I...1...1...didn't know there was going to be so many... Lamarr whips out a derringer and shoots him. The man falls dead.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Draw... (to Cut-Throats) I hope that teaches you a little something about line deportment.

dialogues.speaker: 173A. REAR OF LINE
dialogues.text: Men frantically spitting out gum, tobacco, teeth, etc.

dialogues.speaker: A CLUMP OF ROCKS
dialogues.text: About 15 yards away. Behind the rocks we SEE Bart and Jim scrunched down. Jim is peering over the edge of the rock.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Boy is he strict.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: We gotta get closer.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (points and says) There's our ticket. Bart looks.  175. 90.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF TWO KU KLUX KLANNERS
dialogues.text: in hooded white sheets making their way toward the end of the line. Stenciled on the back of their sheets is: “HAVE A NICE DAY"

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (standing up) Hey fellas. Look what I got here. Ku Klux Klanners stride over. Jim raises Bart up and dis- plays him like a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Oh lordie, lordie. Please don't hurt me. I'm just an old planta- tion darkie who wants to chop cotton and marry into a well-to-do white family.

dialogues.speaker: KKK
dialogues.text: Oh, we got to see to him. Come around here so's we can have him for ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: KRK
dialogues.text: Don't know how to thank you stranger. They step behind the rocks. WE HEAR muffled thuds and gro Two sheeted figures emerge ‘and make their way toward the of the line.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (to Jim) Man that was pretty. I enjoyed that.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Did you have to stick the cactus up his ass?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (in a dreary voice) I had to. They reach the line. They are standing behind a gold toothed Mexican bandit who is signing up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 175 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (to Mexican bandit) Be ready to attack Rock Ridge at noon tomorrow. He hands him a badge.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN BANDIT
dialogues.text: (flinging the badge away) We doan need no steekin' badges. The two hooded figures start to ease away from the line. Too late. They are next.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Next. Bart steps forward. Qualifications:

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Stampeding cattle.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: That's not much of a crime.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Through the Vatican?

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Hmmn. Wonderful. Very different too. Sign here. Bart reaches out to take pen exposing black hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (covering quickly) Rhett, how many times have I told you uIm= to wash up after the weekly~cross ing? Lyle rips off Bart's hood.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: And now for my next impression... Jesse Owens. They flee. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Seize them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two white robed figures are flying down the trail.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: chasing them.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND JIM
dialogues.text: running. They arrive at a fork in the road. Sign pointing toward the right reads:

dialogues.speaker: BAPTISM TODAY
dialogues.text: They turn right. They disappear. Pursuers reach same point. They hesitate and then split up. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: SMALL POND
dialogues.text: Several people in white sheets are either dipping or bein dipped into the water. Bart and Jim come flying INTO FRAM They look at the scene, look at each other and jump into water. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: PURSUERS
dialogues.text: arriving on scene. They are confused. Everyone is in a white sheet.  181.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND JIM
dialogues.text: Jim is dipping Bart furiously in and out of the water. Some of Lamarr's henchmen wade in among people being bapt to scrutinize them more closely.

dialogues.speaker: CUTTHROAT
dialogues.text: (to Jim) Who are you baptising?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (holding Bart under the water) Nobody, just doing my wash. We SEE bubbles, Bart pops up spitting water.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Your wash is drowning. Bart punches Cutthroat unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (pointing) Look. Bart sees what Jim is pointing to: a horse grazing alongs the pond. They make for the horse. Bart jumps up, Jim hop up behind him. They begin to ride off.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: in white sheet in water.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, just what do you fellas think you're doin' with my horse.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND JIM
dialogues.text: on horse.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Stealing it. Bart and Jim ride off.
Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: He stares at them in quizzical resignation.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR'S MEN
dialogues.text: They are on horseback riding furiously in search of Bart and Jim with Taggart in the lead. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Iooks back and see's Taggart's men in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (to Jim) Floor it baby. We've been spotted, Jim urges the horse to greater effort. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: CHASE
dialogues.text: Bart and Jim ride past a stagecoach being held up. Taggart and his men ride by the same stagecoach, cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: C'mon, We're gaining on them. Taggart pulls out his gun and fires, His men follow suit. cuT TO; MASTER SHOT ‘TAGGART'S MEN only 50 yards away.  189. 190. 191. 192. 193. 193A. 95.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND JIM
dialogues.text: Jim suddenly reins up. The horse stops.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: This dumb horse is going to get us killed. C'mon. Let's make a run for it. Bart and Jim jump down and start to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: running like lightning, easily outdistancing Taggart and his men.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART AND HIS MEN
dialogues.text: reining up.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: We'll never catch 'em, now. (angrily throwing down his hat) Sons-of-bitches outsmarted us.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, CAMP SITE NIGHT
dialogues.text: A few railroad workers are asleep around campfire. CAMERA MOVES INTO A CLOSE SHOT of Charlie sleeping peacefully. A black hand ENTERS THE FRAME, taps him on shoulder. Charli (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 193A (Cont.} 194. 195. is starthed, begins to splutter something. Hand covers hi mouth, CAMERA PULLS TQ TWO SHOT to reveal Bart.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (whispering) Charlie, it's me, it's me...Bart. Just say hello. Bart takes his hand off Charlie's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hello. Bart claps his hand over his mouth again.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Now just listen and listen good. I want you to get the brothers to- gether and round up all the Lumber, canvas, nails and paint you can lay your hands on and meet me three miles due East of Rock Ridge tonight at midnight. Understand? Charlie nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now just say goodbye, He takes hand off Charlie's mouth for a second.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Bart claps his hand over his mouth and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRAIRIE NIGHT
dialogues.text: STOCK FOOTAGE of procession of wagons moving along the prairie in the moonlight. We HEAR the squeaking SOUND of a wagon wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal Bart riding up to wagon. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 195 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Get some grease on that wheel, Howard. You can hear it squeaking twenty miles away.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Sheriff, I don't know what you got up your sleeve but you must be pluinb_ loco dragging a whole town out of bed in the middie of the night to God knows where to do God knows what.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Trust me, Bart rides off.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Bart hops

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (to Van Johnson who is viding next to him) Hell, this don't make no sense no how. If we had any brains we'd have pulled out yesterday, headed for Anaheim, California, and hooked up with that Walt Disney feller. He's building like crazy out there,

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay. Stop. Rein up. We're here. down.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SAMUEL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (looking around at emptiness, in lead wagon) Where?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (hopping up on back of wagon addressing townspeople) Now I know you're all confused. Wonder- ing what you're doing out in the middle of the prairie in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (v.0.) Well, speaking for mineself, I'm com- pletely in the dark. (CONTINUED)  98. Revised 2/22/73 196 (Cont.) BART; I'm hip. Now, before the sun comes up we are going to build on this site an exact copy of the town of Rock Ridge. Every building, every store front, every rock and every tree right down to the orange roof on Howard Johnson's outhouse. And when Hedley Lamarr and his men come riding in tomorrow they're gonna attack the wrong place at the wrong time and we'll be waiting. Townspeople ad lib,

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Sheriff, how we gonna do it? We ain't got the time and we ain't got the people.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Wrong and there's why. We HEAR a clanking of wagon wheels, and INTO FRAME, Charlie and Jim come riding out of the dark followed by buckboards filled with railroad workers and con- struction materials.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Who the hell are they?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Railroad workers who have agreed to help us make our dream come true and all they want in return is a little land they can call their own to home- stead. What do you say? There is a lot of grumbling and mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: 197, OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: who speaks for the townsfolk.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: All right. We'll give some Land to the niggers and chinks, but we don't want the Irish. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/73 197 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: No deal. Olson Johnson turns to crowd. They mumble. He turns back to Bart.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: - 4w, prairie shit...everybody.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Thank you, (to all) Okay, folks, let's roll up our sleeves and go to work. Stirring MUSIC begins as crowd collectively rolls up their sleeves and earnestly gets down to work. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: HUGE PIECE OF LUMBER
dialogues.text: being lifted. White arm comes in. Black arm comes in, lumber goes higher. Yellow arm comes in, lumber is almost off the ground. Big green arm comes in and everybody drops it and runs, accompanied by V.O. screams and ad-libs:

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: (v.0.) "What the hell was that!"

dialogues.speaker: HORIZON
dialogues.text: Sun rising slowly, SOUND BUILDS: sawing, hammering and shouting fill the air. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: BACK SECTION OF FAKE ROCK RIDGE
dialogues.text: The men are nailing the last flat into place.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: C'mon, step on it. Sun's almost up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLSON
dialogues.text: (driving last nail into place) That does it. They all whoop for joy. CAMERA PANS off group to SHOT of town. It's a perfect replica of Rock Ridge, except for some prairie grass, cactus and tumbleweed.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (v.a.) Hold it. Hold the happiness, we're in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: We forgot one little thing.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Nothing's missing. It's all there, right down to the last hitching post.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. People...there's no people.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: A cute observation.

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Well, we're people. Why don't we get in there and stand around and then when the murdering cutthroats come riding into town to kill us.... They all stare at Van.

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) You didn't hear it and I didn't say it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Listen. We made a perfect copy of Rock Ridge. Now all we've got to do is make perfect copies of ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: But they'll be here in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Right. We've got to work fast. You men start working on the dummies and you men come with me. I've got an idea that will slow 'em down to a crawl.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Lamarr mounts the steps of a platform.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Men, you are about to embark on a great erusade to stamp out runaway decency in the West. You will all be risking your lives while I will be risking an almost certain academy award nomination for best supporting actor. Please ail rise and remove your hats for the pledge. cuUT TO: of Lamarr's Horde, a collection of the meanest looking eritters ever assembled in Panavision. They rise and re- move their hats.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Your name.

dialogues.speaker: HORDE, (AS ONE)
dialogues.text: -»-Your name ... As Lamarr says pledge leading them, we HEAR collective Ho vV.O. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR LEADING
dialogues.text: (v.o.) -+»pledge allegiance to Hedley Lamarr, and to the evil for which he stands. One scoundrel indisputable with hatred and malice for all.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (with maniacal fervor) Now mount up and DO DO THAT VOODOO THAT YOU DO SO WELL. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: HORDE
dialogues.text: The men are whooping and scrambling wildly for their hors

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRAIRIE DAY
dialogues.text: It is empty. Suddenly we see Bart RIDING INTO FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay put it here.

dialogues.speaker: A TEAM OF HORSES
dialogues.text: pulling a small wooden single-lane toll booth into the center of the prairie. Sign on top of toll booth reads:

dialogues.speaker: GOV. WILLIAM J. LE PETOMANE THRUWAY
dialogues.text: Dangling over the lane is a smaller sign which reads:

dialogues.speaker: EXACT CHANGE LANE
dialogues.text: Jim, Howard and Samuel work together to unhitch the team horses.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (Looking off) Hurry up, they'11 be here any minute. They ride off taking the team of horses with them.  208.
Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: leading horde across the prairie. They suddenly come upon the toll booth. They rein their horses to a screeching halt, SOUND of tires screeching on pavement.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (looking at the toll booth and sign) Le Petomane Thruway. What will that asshole think of next? Who's got a dime? Men ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Someone's gotta go back and get us a shit load of dimes.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: 0.K., Mongo, bring 'm out. curt TO: -

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: pulling a wagon covered with a tarp.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: Heeeeere's Mongo! He reaches crowd, stops and takes off tarp which covers wagon.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: They are obviously pleased with their work. (CONTINUED)
Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: WAGON
dialogues.text: Tt is filled with cardboard replicas of everybody in town, Their heads bob up and down on springs. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS TOWNSPEOPLE
dialogues.text: Townspeople ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: (in panic) Where Mongo? He races around wagon to find himself. At the back of the wagon, we SEE an enormous replica of Mongo.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: (continuing; seeing himself, he breaks into tears and puts ams around his double) Awwww... Mongo.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay, folks, let's get those dummies in place. Townspeople pick up dummies and start carrying them down the street.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Jim) All right, Jim, let's start laying that dynamite.

dialogues.speaker: PRAIRIE TOLL BOOTH
dialogues.text: Tt is a scene of chaos. A long single line of horses and riders stretches back from booth.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: (near the booth) Speed it up. Get your dimes ready. We'll never get to Rock Ridge. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 214 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: MAN ON LINE
dialogues.text: (v.0.) My horse is overheated.

dialogues.speaker: MAN ON HORSE
dialogues.text: Smoke is rising from both sides of the horse's mane,

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Push him off the road. Keep things going. Get more dimes. Shit. Road ain't even paved. It ain't evena road, What the hell do they do with all the money they collect? That's what I'd like to know.

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE OVERLOOKING FAKE ROCK RIDGE
dialogues.text: Bart tying wires to detonator terminals. CAMERA PULLS BACK. We SEE Jim in scene peering through telescope.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hey, Bart, take a look at that.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: It's a stagecoach. .

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Who the hell would be riding in there now? We ZOOM into CLOSE SHOT of stagecoach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the coach we SEE Governor William J. Le Petomane, and his secretary, Miss Stein. They are surrounded by men in frock coats and stovepipe hats. Cards in their hats read "Press". (All the S's are backwards.) (CONTINUED)
Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is making a grotesque face.

dialogues.speaker: MEMBER OF THE PRESS
dialogues.text: Governor, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Harpo Marx, Didn't you care for it? Maybe you'd prefer Tarzan?....Cheeta, where boy...water good, water good.

dialogues.speaker: MEMBER OF THE PRESS
dialogues.text: Please Governor, you were talking about the first integrated town in the West.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Yes, yes...of course. But seriously, folks.....I love a parade, Oh yes... whoo, whoo....I think you'll find Rock Ridge to be a model of peace- ful co-existence never before seen in the annals of the West. There is a loud RINGING noise,

dialogues.speaker: MEMBER OF THE PRESS
dialogues.text: What was that, Governor? Le Petomane slaps his crotch ~-- RINGING stops.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Coach comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: {v.o.) We're here, Governor, Get your ass out.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Get your ass out. Very nice...very nice...get your ass out to the Gover- nor of the state. Governor climbs down from stagecoach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 218A (Cont.) 106A. Revised 2/22/73

dialogues.speaker: LE_ PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (to driver) Can I have you fired?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Sure you can...if you don't mind @ stagecoach strike.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Rumm, rumm, rumm. Good luck to you, you drunken lout, cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: 219, EXT, MAIN STREET FAKE ROCK RIDGE DAY
dialogues.text: They all climb down from the stagecoach.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, let us meet some of the remarkable citizens who have shown America a shining example of tolerance in lieu of hatred...take a shot of me with the wonderful citizens. Press photographer sets up old-fashioned tripod and large box camera. Governor walks over to dumny standing on street. He shakes dummy's hand vigor- ously. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: How are you today, my good man? Dummy's head starts bobbing up and down wildly. Governor puts arm around dummy for picture.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (continuing; to dummy) Can't you hold your goddam head steady for one ieee picture? You're a nervous wreck. Photographer takes the picture.

dialogues.speaker: MEMBERS OF THE PRESS AND MISS STEIN
dialogues.text: Staring at all the dummies in disbelief,

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: walks over and starts flirting with cut-out of Lili in pasties and g-string.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (whispering behind his hand) Find some drapes and wait behind them. I'11l be there as soon as I get rid of these schmucks,

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: We're schmucks.

dialogues.speaker: PRAIRIE TOLL BOOTH
dialogues.text: Last man is going through. We hear "BING" as light turns from red to green.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Okay, men. Move out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 223 (Cont.)
They thunder off.

dialogues.speaker: JIM ON RIDGE
dialogues.text: He is peering through telescope.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: They're through the booth. Okay. We've pers minutes. Bart raises plunger on detonator.

dialogues.speaker: HORDE
dialogues.text: Charging inexorably across the prairie.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (cupping his ear with his hand) Hear that? More people moving into town every day. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: HORDE
dialogues.text: storming town. Their guns are drawn and their faces are portraits of evil anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: PRESS AND MISS STEIN
dialogues.text: They are horrified. They scatter and run for their lives. Governor walks up Main Street, arms flung open, to greet the horde.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: Welcome to Rock Ridge, the first inte- grated community in the West. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 228 (Cont.) Men open FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: LE PETOMANE
dialogues.text: (his clothes tattered and smoking from gunfire;

dialogues.speaker: TO CAMERA
dialogues.text: A little rowdy perhaps but a new territory never attracts the upper middle class right off the bat. Take Australia...please. Why it started with a handful of criminals and convicts. (his hat is shot off) Holy shit, these people are crazy. You'll pardon me as I run for my wonderful life. (he dives into a water trough)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR'S HORDE
dialogues.text: wrecking havoc upon the town, engaging in joyful carnage and senselessly mutilating innocent cardboard cut-outs. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: Bart, Jim, Howard, Samuel, Van, Olson and Lili are there.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (through telescope) Okay, they're all in.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Here we go. Hold your ears, folks. It's showtime. Bart pushes down on the plunger. Nothing happens. Every- one is still holding their ears, Slowly they take their fingers out of their ears. They are bitterly disappointed

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (pointing down the hill at the trailing wire) Der Trebe Ist Gefluchtenschaften. Ve muzz tzu kuntzfabriken.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: What did she say? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GABBY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Ravvid, consarnit suckatash, side- windin' plumbtuckered, mesquite bush- wackered tumbleroughs, maverick... ravvid, ravvid... Everyone takes their hat off and smashes Gabby on the hea

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: The wire's broken.

dialogues.speaker: VAN JOHNSON
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? Any minute now they're going to find out that town is a fake and pull out.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Jim, baby, you think you could squeeze off a shot from here and set off the dynamite?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: What? Hit something over 2,000 yards away with a six-shooter. Can't be done.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: What do you say, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Give ‘er a try. Jim crooks his elbow for support, leans the barrel of his gun over it, Slowly his index finger begins to tighten on the trigger. Everyone stares down toward town expectantly

dialogues.speaker: FAKE ROCK RIDGE
dialogues.text: Taggart kicks in a saloon door and sees nothing but prair on the other side. He shouts back to the men.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: It's fake. We've been suckered in. Taggart hops on his horse and begins to lead his men out.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: He pulls trigger. Gun FIRES. Nothing happens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Missed.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hold on. It takes a little while for it to get there,

dialogues.speaker: FAKE ROCK RIDGE
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the earth is rent by an enormous SERIES

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR'S HORDE
dialogues.text: being blown off their horses. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: BART AND HIS GROUP
dialogues.text: on top of Ridge. From their P.0.V., we SEE the fake town of Rock Ridge EXPLODING in a symphony of cataclysmic destruction. Pieces of the town soar through the air, walls collapse and dummies fly in all directions. Townspeople go crazy with joy. All ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: All right, let's finish them off, Townspeople rush headlong down the ridge, letting loose war-whoops as they attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horde is disoriented, not to mention some who are (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 236 (Cont.) critically injured, Taggart is riding around and trying to recognize the Horde.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: Bad Guys, Bad Guys, pull yourselves together. Here come the Good Guys. It's never been done before in a Western but once, maybe just this once, we beat them. A melee ensues.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Lord. knee to groin) Forgive me, Lord. (knee to groin) Forgive me, Lord... knee to groin)

dialogues.speaker: 237, LILI
dialogues.text: She is singing "Lili Marlene" to a group of weeping German soldiers who are sitting on the ground completely immobilized. They dab tears from their eyes and console each other.

dialogues.speaker: 239, JIM AND BART
dialogues.text: fighting back to back, knocking out Bad Guys.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (to Bart) How ya' doin'?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Great! Bart is punched in stomach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (hollow voice) Make that fair. Bart grabs man who hits him and punches him out. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: He is knocking people out, using an unconscious Bad Guy as a bludgeon. Ten Bad Guys rush him. He knocks them out with his human club. CAMERA BEGINS TO PULL BACK to OVERHEAD SHOT, revealing the huge dimensions of the fight. WE SEE scores of people engaged in vicious, yet somehow entertaining, hand-to-hand combat. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glittering Busby Berkeley set replete with cardboard columns and twin staircases, WE SEE thirty gentlemen decked out in top hats, white ties and tails, holding canes and poised to go into their big number. Around a CAMERA WE SEE a crew and a gay thirties director in jodpurs and beret.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (BUDDY BIZARRE)
dialogues.text: Are Fred and Ginger ready?

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: They're on their marks, Mr. Bizarre.

dialogues.speaker: OFF CAMERA VOICE
dialogues.text: Ready, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY BIZARRE
dialogues.text: Thank you. All right. Very, very, quiet on the set, please...because it's "Magic Time”. Roll it, turn over, action and playback. MUSIC: Hot thirties number comes booming over speakers. Men start tapping their way down the staircases and into our hearts. A loud, rumbling NOISE intrudes itself upon the scene. Suddenly, without warning, a section of the sound stage wall buckles and collapses, Through the (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 243A,
dialogues.text: gaping hole in the sound stage the Black Bart fight pours into the scene. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY BIZARRE
dialogues.text: What's going on here? Is this some kind of grotesque joke? (walking up to Taggart) What the hell do you think you're doing on my set?

dialogues.speaker: TAGGART
dialogues.text: This. He punches Buddy. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DANCER
dialogues.text: They've hit Buddy!! Come on, girls. Dancers rush down the steps, their canes at the ready. The Western types and the chorus boys start mixing it up.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DANCER
dialogues.text: You filthy, yet somehow attractive, Western pig! First Dancer smashes cowboy over the head.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Why you miserable little fruit! Cowboy punches First Dancer out.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Six-gun in hand, he fires TWO SHOTS at ground in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Okay, Pansies, start dancin'. The three gypsies go into a very elaborate life-saving st

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (to Jim) Hey, Jim, baby, do you realize we fought our way all the way up to 1938 CAMERA PULLS BACK to get big view of scene. There's a lot of fighting, mincing, dancing, cursing and, occasionally, kissing.

dialogues.speaker: WARNER BROS, COMMISSARY
dialogues.text: It is filled with actors, extras, etc., wearing a variety of costumes: Bathing beauties in bikinis, Tarzan and Cheetah, confederate soldiers, Southern bells, thirties gangsters, six midget Munchkins from out of the "Wizard o Oz." Some actors are at the counter choosing various food Man dressed as prizefighter, wearing robe, trunks and box ing gloves, is talking to Adolph Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: FIGHTER
dialogues.text: So, how many days you got left, Irv?

dialogues.speaker: ADOLPH HITLER
dialogues.text: Well...what the hell is that!? They turn their heads to the door, Black Bart Brawl spill into commissary. Not only are the Good Guys and the Bad Guys engaged in the fisticuffs, but also many of the danc from the thirties set have been swept along in the fracas It is a rip-roaring beauty of a fight.

dialogues.speaker: TABLES
dialogues.text: covered with food being smashed. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: BAKER MAN
dialogues.text: enters wheeling a cart filled with trays of pies. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 247 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: BAKERY MAN
dialogues.text: (calling out) Bakery man.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (looking at pies) Is that lemon meringue?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He does take into CAMERA, picks up pie and smashes it int Lyle's face.

dialogues.speaker: 249, LYLE
dialogues.text: The pie is dripping off his face. His tongue catches a dr

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: No, that'd be your custard. Another pie flies into his face from OUTSIDE OF FRAME,

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Now, that there's lemon meringue. He faints.

dialogues.speaker: 249A. TAGGART
dialogues.text: He grabs chair. He is about to smash Bart over the head when a huge arm ENTERS FRAME and rips chair out of Taggar hands. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal Mongo. Mongo punches Taggart who slides down the food counter. On route he is covered with an assortment of foods that tumble down on h as he swiftly moves along, The cash register stops his forward motion.

dialogues.speaker: LADY AT REGISTER
dialogues.text: Now, let's see,..we've got Yankee Bean Soup, coleslaw, Tuna Surprise...$3.83. cuUT TO: 250 thru OMITTED. 252. —  253. 254. 255. 256. 117.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY LAMARR
dialogues.text: He is seated at a small table near rear exit of commissar He looks around, takes last sip of coffee, carefully blot his mouth with napkin, pulls his hat down over his eyes a starts to tip-toe out. He grimaces, stops, walks back, leaves a dime tip and starts to tip-toe toward the rear e

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He spots Lamarr sneaking out rear door of commissary. He takes off in Lamarr's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamarr exits on the run, stops on sidewalk panting and gestures to passing taxi.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Taxi. Taxi stops Lamarr enters and SLAMS DOOR. Taxi roars off. CAMERA stays on Warner's gates. Bart emerges on horseback and takes off after taxi,

dialogues.speaker: GRAUMAN'S CHINESE THEATRE
dialogues.text: Marquee reads: "Mel Brooks' BLACK BART starring Cleavon Little, etc. etc.", Taxi pulls up. Lamarr gets out of taxi and rushes to box office window. Ahead of him at the window is a LITTLE OLD LADY fumbling with change in her purse, Lamarr looks over his shoulder nervously as the Little Old Lady continues her quest for $2.50.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST MAN
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Hey, Mother, come over here. I found Hedy Lamar! Hedley does take. Pulls hat down.

dialogues.speaker: V.0.
dialogues.text: I ean't. I'm stuck in Greta Garbo's shoes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 256 (Cont.) Lamarr, fed up with waiting, reaches into his pocket, pul out several bills, He flings bills into the cage.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: It's all right. It's on me. Lamarr picks up Little Old Lady, throws her over his shou and runs into theatre.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: (handing ticket- taker the tickets) We're together.

dialogues.speaker: 257, LITTLE OLD LADY
dialogues.text: hanging over Lamarr's shoulder,

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE OLD LADY
dialogues.text: Nobody cares, nobody ever cares. And then, finally, somebody cares and he's dangerous,

dialogues.speaker: 257A. LOBBY OF GRAUMAN'S CHINESE THEATRE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hedley Lamarr, with Little Old Lady draped over shoulder, runs past a few cows milling about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamarr drapes Little Old Lady across the candy counter an continues on into the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE OLD LADY
dialogues.text: (looking down at candy) Look at that...$2.00 for Neckos. That's outrageous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamarr looks around and ducks into an aisle seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is very interested in what is happening on the screen. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Bart gallops up to front of Graunian's Chinese Theatre an ties his horse to a parking meter.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Watching movie.

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Shit! Lamarr snaps his finger in disgust, bolts out of seat and runs up aisle, cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamarr comes flying out just as Bart begins to enter.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay, Lamarr. This is it. Go for your guns, CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: He raises his hands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 265 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Wait, wait! I'm unarmed. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: 266, BART
dialogues.text: He throws his guns away.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: All right, we'll settle it Like men...with our fists,

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: Oh, oh...sorry... Just remembered. I am armed. Lamarr pulls out a derringer and fires at Bart.

dialogues.speaker: 268, BART
dialogues.text: He hurls himself to the ground, rolls over, picks up his six-shooter and fires all in one motion. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: LAMARR
dialogues.text: He is about to let out another shot when he is hit, The derringer drops out of his hand, He clutches his gut. He spins and falls face down into a square of the traditiona wet cement used to immortalize the hands and feet of scre luminaries. With a dying gasp Lamarr rolls out of the cem leaving his impression. He then signs his name with his forefinger and dies,

dialogues.speaker: 269A. JIM
dialogues.text: He rides up, gets off his horse, walks over to Bart and s veys the scene. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/73 269A (Cont.) 270. 271. Bart and Jim take off their hats slowly~and, look down at the last remains of Hedley Lamarr.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He died like he lived...sideways. Jim looks at him quizzically. (to Jim) I don't know...it's the first thing that came into my head.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Well, that's done. What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's check out the end of the flick. They walk into theatre. CUT TO;

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: MOVIzn SCREEN MAIN STREET ROCK RIDGE MORNING Bar. is on horseback, his saddlebags are packed, As he speaks, CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal towns- peopie and railroad workers formed in a huge semi-circle,

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Sheriff, you can't go now. We need you, Townsfolk ad Llib.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (drawing a deep breath and fixing an eye on a stray cloud) My work here is done. I'm needed elsewhere now. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/73 271 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm needed wherever outlaws rule the West, whereyer innocent women and children are afraid to walk on the streets, wherever a man cannot live in simple dignity and wherever a people ery out for justice.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNS PEOPLE
dialogues.text: (in unison)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: All right, ya caught me. To speak the plain truth, it's getting pretty dam dull around here. Townspeople:ad Lib,

dialogues.speaker: REV. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Good luck, Bart...and God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: MONGO
dialogues.text: He's waving goodbye and weeping copiously, A LITTLE OLD LADY stands underneath him getting drenched.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE OLD LADY
dialogues.text: (to CAMERA; raises umbrella) Have you ever seen such crying?

dialogues.speaker: TOWNS PEOPLE
dialogues.text: ad lib, Bart rides past CHarlie and slaps him off. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 2/22/72 273 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Take care, brother.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Oh, Bart, I'11 never forget you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (staring at her heavy bosom) Don't worry, my dear. I pledge myself to your bosom....comfort, comfort, Strike bosom. Make that comfort. Bart turns around, takes off his hat and waves it to the townsfolk.

dialogues.speaker: . BART
dialogues.text: Keep the faith, niggers. He spurs his horse and moves out, As Bart passes the last building in town and turns the corner, he spots Jim quietly waiting.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (casually) Where ya headin'?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: No where special.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Always wanted to go there.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (smiling) Come on. They ride off together. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PRAIRIE
dialogues.text: FAR SHOT of Bart and Jim riding fquietly off into the sunset. In the corner of the FRAME we SEE a stagecoach being held up. They continue riding for a while and then they rein up and get off (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2/22/73 274 (Cont.) their horses. They stand and wait. Suddenly a large black cadillac limousine drives INTO FRAME. They open the door and get in, As the limousine rides off into the sunset we SEE a small herd of cattle drift across the trail accompanied by their own wonderful cattle sound. We HEAR Lili begin singing “Auf Wiederschen, Adieu, Bye Bye Black Bart".

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: Song continues over END CREDITS and bows from leading characters ending with Bart. In order: The Johnsons: Samuel, Olson, Van, Gabby, Howard and Reverend; Lyle; Mongo; Taggart; Lili; Le Petomane; Lamarr; Jim; and lastly, Bart.
